unicode.value:
CONTEXT

Far in the future, the situation on Earth is dire. Several ecosystems have been wrecked because of human interference and species of animals and plants are dwindling in number. However a group of courageous adventurers, called the Guardians of Biodiversity, has been entrusted the task of restoring the planets ecosystems and ensuring the balance of biodiveersity is maintained. 

The further tasks will involve travelling to different ecosystems on the planet using a special passport conceived by the Guardians. A specific stamp will these participants receive after successfully completing a task, based on solving a problem, which is linked to biodiversity loss and the factors threatening the ecosystems. If there is success in completing all the tasks, history will be made as it will be the first time in the world that society has been granted a key known to unlock a natural object referred to as the Box of Nature.

• SDGs 6: Clean water and sanitation: the different challenges show the importance of water by creating awareness among the students and the possible damages they can generate if they don't stop polluting habits. 
  • SDGs 11: sustainable cities and communities: students come up and create solutions in order to make sustainable communities the best as possible. 
  • SDGs 12: responsible consumption and production: students reflect on responsible habits such as recycling and the reduction of residual waste. 
  • SDGs 14: life below water: overall, students will have a glimpse of the marine ecosystems and their challenges. They will also see the contamination due to plastics, biodiversity lost, and how to preserve marine life. 
  • SDGs 15: life on land: overall, students will see the importance of biodiversity and the balance between biotic and abiotic factors, promoting restoration and protection of terrestrial ecosystems.

• Mathematical Competence and Competences in Science, Technology, and Engineering (MCTSTE): Problem-solving and reasoning skills in mathematics, science, and technology, fostering scientific thinking and decision-making.
  • Digital Competence (DC): Proficiency in the use of digital tools for information management, communication, and problem-solving ethically and safely.
  • Personal, Social, and Learning to Learn Competence (PSLLC): Self-awareness, collaboration, and learning-to-learn skills to navigate personal and social challenges.
  • Cultural Awareness and Expression Competence (CAEC): Appreciation of cultural expressions and fostering creativity in artistic and cultural contexts.

EVALUATION

  • Applies problem-solving strategies in science-related activities.
  • Understand the components and interactions in ecosystems, the importance of biodiversity, and the human impact on the environment while promoting sustainable actions.
  • Demonstrates responsible behavior toward nature.
  • Collaborate effectively, and employ tools and technologies to present solutions to environmental and scientific challenges.

1. How Biotic and Abiotic Components Interrelate in Ecosystems

Biotic components: refer to the living parts of an ecosystem, encompassing plants, animals, microorganisms, fungi, and various organisms. In contrast, abiotic components consist of the non-living factors affecting ecosystems, including sunlight, temperature, water, air, soil, and minerals. 

  • The relationship between biotic and abiotic components is essential for sustaining ecological equilibrium. Sure! Please provide the text you would like me to paraphrase.
  • Plants (biotic) need sunlight (abiotic), water (abiotic), and soil minerals (abiotic) to thrive. 
  • Creatures rely on vegetation for nourishment (biotic) and oxygen for breathing (abiotic). 
  • Microorganisms are vital in nutrient cycling, breaking down dead organic matter and transferring necessary nutrients into the soil for plants. 
  • The interconnectedness of biotic and abiotic components implies that alterations in one aspect (e.g., reduced sunlight, lowered temperatures, or environmental pollution) can trigger ripple effects across the whole ecosystem. 

2. The Effects of Human Activities

Human activities, particularly in recent centuries, have greatly changed ecosystems. Significant ways in which humans influence the environment consist of: 

  • Deforestation: The removal of trees for farming, development, and logging diminishes biodiversity, disrupts ecosystems, and raises carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere. 
  • Pollution: Air, water, and soil contamination (e.g., from industrial waste, plastics, and chemicals) damages both living and non-living elements. For instance, harmful substances can destroy marine organisms, and air contamination can impact plant vitality. 
  • Climate Change: Activities caused by humans, especially the combustion of fossil fuels, have resulted in an increase in greenhouse gases, which contributes to global warming. This impacts temperature trends, rainfall, and ecosystems globally, leading to disturbances such as changed migration routes, melting glaciers, and habitat destruction. 
  • Overfishing and Habitat Loss: Excessive use of resources such as fish and wildlife may result in the extinction of species and a decrease in biodiversity. Moreover, actions such as mining, farming, and urban development obliterate habitats. 

Nevertheless, human behaviors can also lead to beneficial effects: 

  • Conservation Initiatives: Individuals have created protected zones, wildlife sanctuaries, and conservation initiatives to safeguard endangered species and rehabilitate ecosystems. 
  • Sustainable Approaches: Initiatives to implement sustainable farming, clean energy, and minimize waste help diminish harmful effects on ecosystems.

3. Biodiversity and Our Duty to Protect It: 

Biodiversity denotes the range of life on Earth, including genetic variation, species variety, and ecosystem diversity. Biodiversity is crucial for the stability and resilience of ecosystems, as well as for providing services that humans depend on, including clean air, water, food, and medicine. 

Maintaining biodiversity is essential for the following reasons: 

  • Ecosystem Services: Robust ecosystems deliver essential services, including pollination, soil enrichment, water cleansing, climate control, and food cultivation. 
  • Moral Obligation: Being the leading species on Earth, humanity has a duty to safeguard the planet’s diverse life forms. The disappearance of species caused by human activities is permanent and has significant effects. 
  • Cultural and Economic Significance: Numerous cultures rely on biodiversity for their traditional customs, spiritual beliefs, and sustenance.

Furthermore, biodiversity holds significant economic worth, spanning agriculture, tourism, and pharmaceuticals. 
Steps to protect biodiversity involve: 

  • Conservation Initiatives: Creating and implementing safeguarded zones such as national parks, wildlife reserves, and marine protected areas. 
  • Sustainable Resource Utilization: Adopting methods that harmonize human requirements with the well-being of ecosystems, including sustainable practices in forestry, fishing, and agriculture. 
  • Reforestation and Rehabilitation: Planting trees and reviving damaged ecosystems can aid in rebuilding biodiversity and alleviating climate change. 

International collaboration is essential for maintaining biodiversity. Initiatives such as the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) and other global agreements seek to safeguard species and ecosystems worldwide. 

Transversal Material: 

CLIL (Content and Language Integrated Learning) is a pedagogical method that instructs academic subjects like science, history, or mathematics using a foreign language—specifically, English. By combining language acquisition and content education, students gain both subject expertise and language skills. 


English Vocabulary for Science: In natural science, acquiring specific vocabulary in English aids students in grasping intricate ideas such as "ecosystem," "biodiversity," "photosynthesis," "carbon cycle," and "pollution." This enhances students' capacity to converse on scientific subjects within a global framework and provides access to international studies and publications. 

Scientific Vocabulary and Communication: Mastery of English enables students to express their comprehension of natural science, participate in discussions, compose reports, and read scholarly articles within the international scientific community. 

  • Cognitive Abilities: CLIL fosters cognitive advantages by improving problem-solving, analytical thinking, and critical analysis skills. When students interact with material in a second language, they gain a more profound comprehension of both the language and the content. 
    Social accountability encompasses the notion that individuals, organizations, and governments ought to be accountable for their actions and decisions, particularly concerning their effects on society, the environment, and future generations. 
  • Personal Accountability: At an individual level, social responsibility involves being mindful of one's choices, like minimizing waste, saving energy, backing ethical companies, and participating in community initiatives for social and ecological issues. 
  • Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR): Companies are progressively being held responsible for their social and environmental influence. This may include lowering carbon emissions, advocating for equitable labor practices, assisting community growth, and maintaining sustainability in their activities. 
  • Government Accountability: Governments are essential in promoting social accountability via legislation, policy formulation, and public service delivery. Governments must ensure that policies safeguard public health, maintain the environment, and encourage social justice. Transparency and public involvement in decision-making processes are vital elements of accountability. 
  • Global Responsibility: Social responsibility also encompasses worldwide matters like climate change, human rights, and global trade. Nations and global organizations need to collaborate in order to tackle worldwide issues. For instance, the Paris Agreement regarding climate change represents a global pledge to reduce global warming and enhance sustainability. 

Social accountability is essential for cultivating a fairer, sustainable, and responsible world. By embracing accountability, communities can collaborate to address urgent global issues such as environmental decline, inequality, and social injustice.

Universal Design for Learning (UDL): UDL offers flexible approaches to teaching. In our sessions, we offer: 

  • Multiple Means of Representation: Present content in diverse ways (visual, auditory, kinesthetic).
  • Multiple Means of Action and Expression: It allows students to express understanding in their preferred way.
  • Multiple Means of Engagement: Use activities that tap into students' interests and provide appropriate challenges.

Scaffolding: our activities have appropriate scaffolded points to help the students complete the tasks and also, we guide them through the whole process. We break complex tasks into smaller steps and provide tools (e.g., visual aids, and graphic organizers) to guide students gradually toward independence.


Cooperative learning: 

Encourage group work where students collaborate to achieve shared goals. They work together to accomplish each mission. Each member of the group will provide different skills and knowledge, mixing all kinds of abilities and being points of learning. It also promotes peer support and social skills building.

• Gamification: students have to engage in missions. These missions are active problem-solving. 
  • Challenged-based learning: an instructional approach that encourages students to learn through solving real-world problems or mostly in our case, challenges. 
  • Collaborative learning: there are a lot of activities where they have to work in groups, building social and civic skills.

In a world full of natural wonders, ecosystems are alive: the rainforest, the oceans, the forests and the deserts. But the Guardians of Biodiversity have detected warning signs. Deforestation, pollution and climate change are seriously affecting the fauna and flora in every corner of the planet. The future of the Earth depends on us.


Entire ecosystems are in danger of disappearing, and the animals and plants that depend on them are losing their homes. That's why we need a team of explorers like you. Do you want to help us?


Every step we take on this mission will be a challenge. You will have to face different challenges in which you will have to think like true Guardians of Biodiversity: identify the threats facing ecosystems, find innovative solutions and learn to protect life on Earth. But you will not be alone! Each time you overcome a challenge, you will receive a stamp in your passport. If you manage to obtain all the stamps, you will be able to unlock the secret that will save the planet.

The students looked at their passports. Each page had a space for ecosystem stamps, marking the different challenges they would face. The first challenge: “Save the Rainforest.” The Guardians had to demonstrate how deforestation affects species and how they can restore balance. 

In this presentation that we are going to read, there are hidden clues. These clues will help us complete a series of challenges. Only if we solve all the challenges, we will be able to get the grand final prize!

Copia de ECOSYSTEMS de Eva Fernández

In this word search, you will find some key words that are part of what we have read in the presentation. The words are hidden in all directions: from top to bottom, from left to right, from right to left and even diagonally! To complete the challenge, you must find all the words related to what we have learned so far.

Hallar las palabras ocultas.

%E7%F7%F5%FD%BC%BC%BC%B0%BE%B0%FF%F5%E1%D5%F3%FF%F7%C1%E6%F3%E0%E6%B0%A8%B0%D7%FE%B2%F8%E7%F7%F5%FD%B2%EB%F3%B2%FA%F3%B2%F1%FD%FF%F7%FC%E8%F3%F6%FD%BC%B0%BE%B0%FF%E1%F5%CB%FD%E7%C1%F1%FD%E0%F7%B0%A8%B0%C2%E7%FC%E6%E7%F3%F1%FBa%FC%B0%BE%B0%FF%E1%F5%D7%FC%F6%C6%FB%FF%F7%B0%A8%B0%D3%F1%F3%F0a%B2%F7%FE%B2%E6%FB%F7%FF%E2%FD%B2%F6%F7%B2%F8%E7%F7%F5%FD%BC%B2%C6%E7%B2%E2%E7%FC%E6%E7%F3%F1%FBa%FC%B2%F7%E1%B2%B7%E1%BC%B0%BE%B0%FF%E1%F5%D7%FC%F6%B0%A8%B0%D4%FB%FC%F3%FE%FB%E8%F3%E0%B0%BE%B0%FF%E1%F5%D7%FC%F6%D5%F3%FF%F7%DF%B0%A8%B0%DA%F3%E1%B2%F1%FD%FF%E2%FE%F7%E6%F3%F6%FD%B2%F7%FE%B2%F8%E7%F7%F5%FD%BC%B2%C6%E7%B2%E2%E7%FC%E6%E7%F3%F1%FBa%FC%B2%F7%E1%B2%B7%E1%BC%B0%BE%B0%FF%E1%F5%C7%FC%F1%FD%FF%E2%FE%F7%E6%F7%F6%D3%F1%E6%FB%E4%FB%E6%EB%B0%A8%B0%D3%F1%E6%FB%E4%FB%F6%F3%F6%B2%FC%FD%B2%F1%FD%FF%E2%FE%F7%E6%F3%F6%F3%B0%BE%B0%FF%E1%F5%C1%E7%F1%F1%F7%E1%E1%F4%E7%FE%D3%F1%E6%FB%E4%FB%E6%EB%B0%A8%B0%D3%F1%E6%FB%E4%FB%F6%F3%F6%B2%E1%E7%E2%F7%E0%F3%F6%F3%BC%B2%C2%E7%FC%E6%E7%F3%F1%FBa%FC%A8%B2%B7%E1%B0%BE%B0%FF%E1%F5%C7%FC%E1%E7%F1%F1%F7%E1%E1%F4%E7%FE%D3%F1%E6%FB%E4%FB%E6%EB%B0%A8%B0%D3%F1%E6%FB%E4%FB%F6%F3%F6%B2%FC%FD%B2%E1%E7%E2%F7%E0%F3%F6%F3%BC%B2%C2%E7%FC%E6%E7%F3%F1%FBa%FC%A8%B2%B7%E1%B0%BE%B0%FF%E1%F5%C6%EB%E2%F7%D5%F3%FF%F7%B0%A8%B0%C1%FD%E2%F3%B2%F6%F7%B2%FE%F7%E6%E0%F3%E1%B0%EF%EF
0123456789
Su navegador no es compatible con esta herramienta.
Well done! Now you will receive the first stamp.

Today, our adventure begins in an amazing place — the terrestrial ecosystem, the world we live in! As inhabitants of this planet, it's important to understand how our actions affect the environment around us. We will start by exploring how we, as humans, are part of this ecosystem and how our choices can either help or harm the Earth. Get ready to learn about the delicate balance that keeps everything alive and how we can make a difference in protecting it. Let the adventure begin!

We are going to continue with yesterday´s lesson, but today we will talk about human actions! Are you ready? Let´s go.

Copia de ECOSYSTEMS de Eva Fernández

The first challenge of today will be Matching cards! Once you reach the session, one appointed student will have to collect the cards for this challenge. Therefore, go to your teacher, she will give it to you. 

Once you have it, follow the instructions:

1. In table groups, you will have to match the correponding cards.

2. Identify and classify examples of biotic and abiotic interactions, human impacts, and biodiversity preservation efforts.

3. There are 3 categories

  • Biotic and Abiotic Interactions
  • Human Impacts
  • Biodiversity Preservation Efforts

4. You will have to place in the correct category the following cards:

Today, our adventure begins in a very special place, the aquatic ecosystem! This is a world full of life beneath the surface of lakes, rivers, and oceans. But before we dive into the water and meet the creatures that live there, we need to understand something very important: our role as inhabitants of this ecosystem.

As humans, our actions can have a big impact on the aquatic world around us. So, let’s start by learning about how we, as part of nature, can help protect and care for this amazing environment. Are you ready to explore the underwater world and discover how we can make a difference?

Let’s begin our adventure!

Today we will read a text, but first, pay attention to the instructions.

Green Aesthetic Nature Forest Presentation de Eva Fernández
Green White Illustration Forest Simple Page Border A4 Document de Eva Fernández

Today, your adventure begins in one of the most fascinating ecosystems on Earth: the desert. This is a place where life has learned to survive with very little water and extreme temperatures. You’ll meet creatures that are experts at hiding from the sun, plants that store water like treasure, and learn how everything in this ecosystem is connected.

Your mission is to explore the desert, solve challenges, and collect stamps for your Explorer's Passport. Pay close attention, work together, and discover the secrets of this incredible place. Each challenge will bring you closer to unlocking the final treasure. Are you ready to begin?

Good morning, adventurers! Today is a special day because our great adventure begins right here, in our own neighborhood. Look around—every street, every tree, and every corner is part of a bigger story waiting to be discovered.

This is not just any neighborhood. It’s a place full of mysteries, challenges, and hidden treasures. Together, we’ll explore, learn, and uncover the secrets of the world starting right here, where we live.

Are you ready to begin? Let’s step outside, open our eyes wide, and let the adventure unfold! Today, the journey starts at home.

Good morning, adventurers! Today is a special day because our great adventure begins right here, in our own neighborhood. Look around—every street, every tree, and every corner is part of a bigger story waiting to be discovered.

This is not just any neighborhood. It’s a place full of mysteries, challenges, and hidden treasures. Together, we’ll explore, learn, and uncover the secrets of the world starting right here, where we live.

Are you ready to begin? Let’s step outside, open our eyes wide, and let the adventure unfold! Today, the journey starts at home.
What is in my bag? Instructions

In today´s activity, you are going to work on the Session 1 and 2 vocabulary.

Every travller and guardian needs a good bag. For that reason, every group will have one bag. In that bag you will have to stick the card “I have…”, in the space with the number 1.

Then you have to relate the words of the cards with the images you have, according to the group they belong to (e.g. Word: "descomposer" - image: "fungi"), and stick the ones that you recognize. You will stick those in spaces number 2.

When you finish, you will have to tell the rest groups of the class what is what you have in yout bags. You will have to start every sentence by saying: “I have in my bag a… that is a ....” (e.g.: I have in my bag a fungi that is a descomposer). While you tell the word, you have to point to the image you have stuck in the bag. All of the group members have to speak.
Teaching bag de Eva Fernández

Now that we’ve finished the activity, it’s time to write about your experience! In your notebook, write a short paragraph answering these questions:

  1. What did you find in your bag?
  2. How did you decide which group each item belonged to?
  3. What was the most interesting or surprising thing in your bag? Why?
  4. How did you feel when you presented your bag to the class?

Be creative! You can describe how your group worked together, what you learned, and anything funny or challenging that happened. Make sure to use the sentence structure we practiced:

"In our bag, we had a ______ that is a ______."


Write at least 5-6 sentences. If you want, you can add drawings of the items you described!

Hello, young explorers!

Today, our exciting adventure begins in a very special place: the coastal ecosystem. Imagine the waves crashing on the shore, the salty breeze in the air, and the sun warming the sand. This is a home not just for us when we visit the beach, but for countless plants, animals, and even tiny living creatures you can barely see!

But did you know that as visitors and inhabitants of this amazing ecosystem, our actions have a big impact here? Before we dive into our adventure, we’ll learn about how we can take care of this incredible place. Together, we’ll discover what we do that helps or harms the coast and what makes this ecosystem so important for everyone.

Get ready, because today we’re not just visitors—we’re coastal heroes on a mission to protect and explore the wonders of the sea and the shore. Let’s start learning and have fun along the way!

First you will play a Ecosystem race. Roll the dice, advance the squares and answer the questions.
Solutions:

You will play a Pictionary + Dice questions.

One of the group  members will go to the blackboars, the teacher will show him or her a card with a word. That person will have 1 minute to try to represent that word with a drawing, the rest of the group will have to discover the word. If they get it right, that group will get 1 point.

Then, that person will roll a dice, which has 6 different options according to the color:

1. Biodiversity cards - specific questions with specific answers about what we have been learning.

2. Human action cards - questions in the ones you will have to reflect about if an action is good or bad and why.

3.  Create solution cards - questions in the ones you have to create an efficient solution for a specific problem.

4. Another group decides which card you will have to answer to.

5. Your group decides which card to answer to.

6. Your teacher decides which card you have to answer to.

The person that has drawn the previous word has to read the question out loud. The rest of the group has to decide an answer. After they tell the answer, the person with the card will read out loud the solution written in the card. If you get it right, you will get an extra point.
Ecosystem pictionary de Eva Fernández
Biodiversity cards de Eva Fernández

Congratulations, explorers! You’ve completed your journey through the desert and discovered the amazing ways life thrives in such a harsh environment.

Look at your Explorer's Passport—if you’ve collected all the stamps, it’s time to open the treasure box! Inside, you’ll find a special reward for your hard work and teamwork.

Thank you for joining this adventure and becoming desert experts. Remember, every ecosystem has its own story, and there are so many more to explore.

Until next time, keep learning and keep exploring!
